title: Bust the Police Unions to Rank and Yank Bad Cops
summary: Officials need the ability to fire low-performing officers and reward ones who go above and beyond.. The police officer who killed George Floyd had been the subject of more than a dozen complaints about his conduct. In two previous incidents, Derek Chauvin had been disciplined with letters of reprimand. Tou Thao, who stood by as Floyd died, previously had a lawsuit brought against him over excessive use of force. The lawsuit was settled for $25,000. How can such men be allowed to "serve and protect"? Unions.

title: Michael Moore's Inconvenient Half-Truth
summary: The lefty filmmaker finds green energy a capitalist scam but learns nothing about climate science.. Most of what left-wing film producer Michael Moore has to say about green energy in his latest film, "Planet of the Humans," is right: These technologies have nasty environmental impacts as do all products of industrial civilization. They are not going to make a dent in CO2.

title: My Benevolent Incarceration in a New Jersey Senior Home
summary: Extreme precautions are justified, but aren't we at greater risk from the staff than the other residents?. Highland Park, N.J.

title: Violent Protest and the Intelligentsia
summary: Scholar Gary Saul Morson sees disturbing parallels between Russia before the Revolution and contemporary America.. The similarities between this week's riots and the Los Angeles riots of 1992 are obvious. Both were occasioned by appalling video images, and both divided the nation along partisan and ideological lines. The differences between the two events, however, are more revealing. The violence in 1992 came after a court verdict; the beating and arrest of Rodney King had happened more than a year before. This year's riots came within days of George Floyd's killing by Minneapolis officers. The riots of 1992 were mostly confined to poor and working-class areas of Los Angeles. This week saw mayhem all over America, and in Los Angeles, New York and elsewhere the rioters targeted wealthy streets and neighborhoods.

title: The Economy Rises From the Dead
summary: The job market heals faster than expected as the lockdowns ease.. Friday's surprisingly upbeat jobs report for May was no doubt cheered by most Americans, but not by all. Democrats Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer seemed glum, as they ignored the progress and demanded still more federal money. What do they have against good economic news?

title: A Minor IRS Miracle
summary: A new rule exempts more nonprofits from filing donor data.. Federal agencies don't typically give up discretionary power, so it's worth applauding the Internal Revenue Service, believe it or not. Late last week it published a final rule that relieves most 501(c) nonprofits of a requirement to report the names and addresses of major donors. The IRS "does not need" the information "to administer the internal revenue laws," said the Treasury Department, and it changed the rule "in light of the risks and burden."

title: Waiting for the Biden Bailout
summary: Liberal states refuse to cut spending as they wait for 2021.. American workers and businesses have had to cut their spending for weeks amid the pandemic, but in America's most spendthrift states the message is: What, me worry? House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has a plan to bail them out, and if she fails Joe Biden will deliver in 2021.

title: Dozens Arrested in New York Protests to Remain in Jail
summary: Judge rejects argument by Legal Aid Society that extended detentions violate state law. A New York state court judge refused to release dozens of people arrested as a result of protests and looting in Manhattan following the killing of George Floyd.

title: Trump to Pull Thousands of U.S. Troops From Germany
summary: Move would cut 9,500 American service members from Germany, where 34,500 are permanently assigned, amid strains between two key NATO allies. President Trump has directed the Pentagon to remove thousands of American troops from Germany by September, a move that would dramatically reshape the U.S. military posture in Europe and reflects growing tensions between Washington and Berlin over military spending and other security issues, U.S. government officials said Friday.

title: Washington Gears Up for Huge Saturday Protests
summary: Organizers, police expect rallies at major landmarks to draw biggest crowds since George Floyd's death. WASHINGTON-Activists and city officials are planning for huge gatherings on Saturday near the White House and other Washington landmarks as demonstrators push on with their call for wholesale justice reform after the killing of George Floyd.

title: Two on John Tyler: Tippecanoe and Tyler Too!
summary: After the Whig president's shocking death, his vice president and successor proved to be a Whig by expedience only. Think of campaign slogans as soundbites before there were soundbites. "I Like Ike" may have offered little guidance to Dwight Eisenhower's priorities or likely performance in office, but in 1952 it warmly and successfully rebranded the GOP, stamped for the previous generation of Americans as the party of breadlines and Hoovervilles. Likewise, in the 19th century the short-lived Whig party relied on another iconic catchphrase to broaden its appeal during the period of severe economic hardship that began with the Panic of 1837: "Tippecanoe and Tyler Too!" It was the byword for hope and change during the election of 1840.

title: 'The Deficit Myth' Review: Years of Magical Thinking
summary: At least Bernie Sanders believes spending depends on tax revenue. Modern monetary theory says: Dream big!. Modern monetary theory, known as MMT, erupted suddenly into the public consciousness when it won the attention of high-profile politicians including Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and their media admirers. Its central proposition states that the U.S. federal government can and should freely print money to finance a massive spending agenda, with no concern about debt and deficits.

title: 'Rivers of Power' Review: The Force That Flows
summary: It's hard to imagine a world without rivers.. It's hard to imagine a world without rivers. The continents would be higher, colder and more rugged, and we humans might still be hugging the coastlines. Our iconic cities, situated along rivers, would not have been built. Global trade and travel might never have developed. Even so, rivers' crucial role in shaping civilization is "grandly underappreciated," according to Laurence C. Smith, professor of earth, environmental and planetary sciences at Brown University. In his important new book "Rivers of Power," he surveys mankind's long, shifting relationship with our rivers, ranging from prehistory to the present and embracing nearly every region of the world.

title: 'Ornette Coleman' Review: Gone to the Territory
summary: His music gave rise to a scene, a whole ecology of people thinking new thoughts and doing good work.. When friends, family and admirers filled Manhattan's Riverside Church to celebrate the life of Ornette Coleman, who died in 2015 at the age of 85, an opening procession was led by members of the Master Musicians of Jajouka, from Morocco. They were among the long, diverse list of collaborators with Coleman, who, as alto saxophonist and bandleader, occasional violinist and trumpeter, and Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, was the most unbound and least predictable figure in jazz history. That day, pianist Cecil Taylor, Coleman's contemporary, played with a combination of solemnity and joy that suggested Coleman's own distinct blend. Tap dancer Savion Glover and drummer Jack DeJohnette wrung melody from rhythm, just as Coleman had.

title: U.S. Files Charges Against Chinese N95 Mask Maker
summary: Subpar masks from King Year Printing and Packaging could have put American front-line workers at risk, prosecutors allege. Federal prosecutors charged a Chinese manufacturer with exporting nearly a half million masks to the U.S. that falsely purported to be N95 respirators, saying the subpar products could have put health-care workers at risk amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Stock Exchanges Win Legal Battle With SEC Over Data Fees
summary: A court rejects the regulator's decision to reject fee increases. U.S. stock exchanges won a legal battle with their regulator on Friday when an appeals court ruled some fee increases can't be challenged by the government after they have taken effect.

title: Major Fixes Made to Small-Business Loan Program
summary: Trump signs bill addressing complaints of some business owners seeking aid. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Friday signed into law a bill giving companies more time and flexibility to spend funds from the federal aid program to help small businesses during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Stocks Are Rallying Despite Nationwide Protests. That's Typical.
summary: Rather than focusing on economic data and civil unrest, some traders are betting on an economic recovery and corporate earnings. title: Travelport Owners Defy Lenders to Supply Up to $1 Billion Financing
summary: Elliott Management and Siris Capital Group affiliates provided a loan package to help Travelport weather the coronavirus pandemic, while suing lenders that have objected. Siris Capital Group LLC and Elliott Management Corp. affiliates are supplying up to $1 billion in financing to their struggling travel-booking platform Travelport Worldwide Ltd., defying the company's lenders and touching off a legal fight.

title: The Spy Novelist and Covid-19 Skeptic at Center of Amazon Controversy
summary: Booklet written by spy novelist and ex-journalist was temporarily rejected by company's self-publishing unit. Alex Berenson has spent much of his career as an investigative business reporter and a writer of spy thrillers. Now his skepticism of how governments are handling the Covid-19 crisis has put him at the center of a controversy over the pandemic and Amazon.com Inc.'s market power.

title: Finding the Glory Beneath the Grime
summary: A yearslong cleaning and repair effort has restored the Church of The Red Monastery's brilliant paintings.. The Church of The Red Monastery (Dayr Anba Bishay) stands at the edge of a desert escarpment overlooking the Nile floodplain in Upper Egypt, about 300 miles south of Cairo. The name derives from the red bricks used to construct the walls of the church. Once the center of a thriving community of Christian ascetics, this impressive late fifth-century church was until recently almost completely ignored. Centuries of ritual practice using incense, oil lamps and candles slowly coated the interior of the church sanctuary with thick deposits of soot. Over half a millennium after its creation, medieval monks further obscured the interior by building mud-brick reinforcing walls, likely in response to earthquakes. The dry climate and internal walls protected fabulous and exceptionally rare paintings. In the early 20th century, a conservation group removed the internal mud brick walls of the sanctuary, but did not touch the paintings.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Deaths Pass 108,000; India Reports Its Highest Daily Toll
summary: Brazil becomes No. 3 in pandemic deaths after U.S., U.K.. • The U.S. coronavirus death toll passed 108,000 while reported cases topped 1.8 million, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. Cases world-wide neared 6.7 million, and deaths stood at more than 393,000. Experts say official totals likely understate the extent of the pandemic, in part because of differing testing and reporting standards.

title: Investors Sell Safe Bets
summary: U.S. government bond yields surge and gold prices tumble after Friday's better-than-expected jobs report. title: Stocks Surge on Surprisingly Upbeat Jobs Report
summary: The Dow industrials climbed 3.2%, while the Nasdaq Composite fell just shy of its all-time closing peak. title: The Old Liberal Order Is Under Siege
summary: In the past two weeks, Black Lives Matter has essentially converged with the entire modern U.S. establishment, from academia to the media to corporate leaderships. title: Despite a Week of Tumult, Trump Claims Victory
summary: Despite nationwide protests and criticism from fellow Republicans and military leaders, the president touted his performance on the economy and the coronavirus. WASHINGTON-President Trump claimed victory on multiple fronts on Friday, crediting his administration for the drop in unemployment and its response to the coronavirus pandemic after a week marked by protests across the nation and rebukes from Democrats, congressional Republicans and former members of his administration.

title: Hydroxychloroquine Doesn't Help Hospitalized Covid-19 Patients, New Research Finds
summary: Researchers said they stopped the study evaluating hydroxychloroquine after a preliminary analysis found no survival or other benefit. Researchers testing whether the antimalaria drug hydroxychloroquine helped hospitalized Covid-19 patients said Friday they halted the U.K.-based study after a preliminary analysis showed the pill didn't provide a benefit.

The Trump administration eased off plans to block passenger flights by mainland Chinese airlines to the U.S. on Friday, after China said it would permit some passenger flights by U.S. airlines.

title: OPEC, Allies to Finalize Oil-Cut Extension After Resolving Dispute
summary: Deal is set to be confirmed Saturday following promises from Iraq, Nigeria to improve compliance. OPEC and its allies are set to meet Saturday to finalize an extension of their record oil production curbs through July, delegates said, after the world's largest exporters resolved a dispute over compliance and move cautiously to rebalance crude markets.

summary: With no national standards, technology giants become gatekeepers in market; 'we've seen bad privacy practices'. When users open the Contact Tracing app on their phones, they expect to see an alert saying where they were exposed to the new coronavirus.

summary: Parcel and warehouse companies added more than 20,000 jobs as online sales demand surged. Logistics operators tied to e-commerce added jobs in big numbers in May as homebound consumers stepped up online shopping while the broader economy showed signs of recovery from the shock of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Contact Tracing, Covid-19 and Big Brother
summary: And yes, the patient's identity is protected due to HIPAA but most people I've called know the patient. How else would they be exposed? They are usually a father, husband, wife, friend.. I am a volunteer contact tracer in Monroe County (Rochester, N.Y.). Peggy Noonan's "The Challenge of Contact Tracing in America" (Declarations, May 30) struck a nerve. Ms. Noonan only partially understands contract tracing. She is correct about contacting and quarantining people who have been in close proximity with a positive Covid-19 person. But the contacts identified by a positive patient aren't asked for their contacts "and so on." And yes, the patient's identity is protected due to HIPAA but most people I've called know the patient. How else would they be exposed? They are usually a father, husband, wife, friend. The exposed contacts include children. However, they are also asked if they need assistance with groceries, medicines.

title: Should U.S. Invite Hong Kongers to Settle?
summary: President Trump's statement of solidarity with Hong Kong is welcome, but bringing the human talent of Hong Kong to the U.S. would be a substantive policy change.. Regarding your editorial "Visas for Hong Kong" (May 30): President Trump's statement of solidarity with Hong Kong is welcome, but bringing the human talent of Hong Kong to the U.S. would be a substantive policy change that you believe would enhance America, hurt China and stun critics of his otherwise anti-immigration rhetoric and policies. The election-year political effect of a pro-immigration shock might not be worth the risk. President Trump's critics are unlikely to change their minds, the bold move will be portrayed as a stunt by most in the media and his base may not appreciate his wavering on immigration, especially when many of his supporters are unemployed because of the pandemic.

title: Return of the Jobs Boom
summary: May's great hiring news sparks another media conspiracy theory.. Americans desperate for good news received a huge helping on Friday, with the Labor Department's report of a nationwide hiring surge in May. The latest Trump-era jobs increase is so encouraging that it inspired a New York Times columnist to float another fact-free conspiracy theory. Should we call it Trump Employment Syndrome?

title: Telling Time With a Work of Art
summary: A Christie's auction of Cartier clocks shows why they have been objects of desire for over a century.. "I do not count the hours if they are not brilliant," says the Latin motto on a clock made by Cartier in 1913. Fittingly, the 4-inch timepiece is crammed with gold, rose-cut diamonds and shades of white and blue enamel. It is among 101 Cartier clocks that will be auctioned online by Christie's from July 7 to July 21-possibly the largest auction ever of clocks from the 173-year-old company. Christie's estimates that the clocks, amassed over the decades by an anonymous private collector, will fetch a total of more than $4 million.

title: Fire Burns Massive Southern California Warehouse

summary: A study suggests that executives are more likely to share valuable insight with an analyst who has the same first name. For securities analysts, there might be more in a name than Shakespeare's Juliet ever imagined.

title: Where Employment Improved-and Where It Didn't
summary: Resume Subscription. Employment rebounded broadly in May as companies reopened following coronavirus shutdowns. Among goods-producing industries, manufacturing showed strong gains. In the services category, jobs in food services and drinking places rose by 1.4 million, accounting for about half of the gain in total nonfarm employment. On the other hand, government payrolls continued to shrink as steep declines in revenue forced cities and states to lay off workers.

title: Britain's 'Professor Reopen'
summary: The experts are said to insist lockdown is necessary to combat coronavirus. Epidemiologist Sunetra Gupta dissents.. A woman with whom Neil Ferguson was carrying on an extramarital affair visited him twice, the first time a week into the lockdown. Mr. Ferguson, whose advice to lock down had been pivotal, was forced to resign from the government's Covid response team.

The premise of the book, which takes place entirely in India, follows the story of a poor Muslim woman who is accused of terrorism after posting a message critical of the government on Facebook.

"So I'm grateful to be working and maintaining positivity." Almost three months ago, the Herbfarm, outside Seattle, where he is the chef, closed to customers. Yet Mr. Weber's been working longer hours than ever to feed frontline hospital workers, at times over 300 a day. (Funds for the program are dwindling, he said, so it will likely end this week.)

title: America's Employment Crisis Has Turned the Corner
summary: There are all kinds of reasons to doubt the accuracy of Friday's jobs report. That doesn't mean it should be ignored.. There are all kinds of reasons to doubt the accuracy of Friday's employment report. That doesn't mean the underlying message that the job market may have passed its nadir should be ignored.

title: The Long Reach of Racism in the U.S.
summary: Despite great progress across two centuries, exclusion and injustice remain the reality for too many black Americans. One of the many ways, good and bad, in which America is truly exceptional is its experience of race-its tortured embrace of black Americans and the paradoxical extremes in how it treats them. Race is the fulcrum upon which two radically different visions of America pivot. In the inhuman, banal killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis we see the reactivated weight of the country's darkest past. In the nationwide demonstration of young blacks and whites against it and other recent racist killings, we see the outraged, countervailing force of that other America which Martin Luther King Jr. imagined as the "beloved community."

title: Jimmy Chin Looks for New Peaks to Climb
summary: The adventurer and photographer who co-directed 'Free Solo' is back home during the pandemic but planning new expeditions. For over 20 years, the climber and photographer Jimmy Chin has spent more than half his year traveling and on risky expeditions, from trying to climb an arduous, rarely attempted route up Everest without supplemental oxygen to venturing to ski a new line down Antarctica's Mt. Vinson earlier this year. The Covid-19 pandemic has kept him home for the longest time in his career. "It's the most consecutive days I've had with my kids, ever," he says.

title: Beauty Routine Tricks That Emphasize De-Stressing
summary: Facial massage and other touch-based practices performed regularly at home help reduce stress and offer a sense of calm. Like any ritualistic practice, daily beauty routines can have a distinctly grounding effect. "Routines are really important as they give us a sense of control over our day and our life," says Dr. Amy Wechsler, who is board-certified in both dermatology and psychiatry. "And they're often the first things to go out the window during periods of stress." She counsels her patients to keep up their routines-especially in terms of skin care-as much as possible. "Right now we all feel completely out of control," says Wechsler. "There's a lot of uncertainty and so many people telling us what we can and can't do. Anything we can do to regain a bit of control is important."

title: Online Fitness Classes: 6 of the Most Entertaining
summary: From virtual dance parties to boxing rounds, these high-energy group fitness classes are all available virtually-good news for introverts who can let loose in blissful privacy. But while extroverts may be missing their posse and those floor-to-ceiling mirrors, introverts can finally dance like no one's watching.

title: BNY Mellon Whistleblower Who Revealed Currency Abuses Gets $50 Million

title: Mysteries: Local Politics and Global Espionage
summary: A washed-up investigative journalist stumbles on a vote-rigging scheme devised by a foreign mastermind.. Investigative journalist Jack Sharpe, protagonist in David Pepper's intrigue-filled third novel, "The Voter File" (Putnam, 423 pages, $27), has some major achievements on his resume: "I'd taken down a presidential front-runner . . . and inspired a year of bipartisan reform on Capitol Hill." But Sharpe is on a slide after being fired from his high-profile job as a TV talking head. He's desperate for a career-reviving scoop when he answers a message from Victoria (Tori) Justice, a rugby-playing Wisconsin college student and part-time political campaign worker who claims that she has a sensational story: She's certain that the recent special election for a vacancy on her state's Supreme Court was rigged (in favor of her candidate) through interference with carefully guarded voter files.

title: 'Dead Reckoning' Review: Taking Aim at a Target of One
summary: 'Operation Vengeance,' carried out in the South Pacific in April 1943, was perhaps America's first targeted killing of an enemy leader.. By April 1943, the United States had finally gone on the offensive against Japan, invading and holding the South Pacific island of Guadalcanal at the price of 29 ships, 600 warplanes and 15,000 men killed or wounded, with Japanese losses higher in every category. It would be the first of many bloody victories as the U.S. started "climbing the rungs of a ladder" that led to Tokyo. Dick Lehr, a professor of journalism at Boston University, quotes that felicitous phrase in "Dead Reckoning," his dramatic account of America's effort to "avenge" Pearl Harbor with the assassination of Japanese Adm. Yamamoto.

title: Corporate Activism Gets Its Day. Ben & Jerry's Has Been At It for Decades.
summary: The battle over any issue worth fighting for lasts longer than a news cycle. Just ask the maker of Cherry Garcia and Pecan Resist.. Almost everything a business does can be measured. summary: For years, big U.S. firms were Beijing's most reliable allies in Washington. Now they're taking a harder stand..

title: Fiction: No One Speaks Our Language Any More
summary: A dictionary of Wiradjuri words compiled by an Australian woman's grandfather is a window on her family's aboriginal roots.. A verse from Proverbs appears in Tara June Winch's "The Yield" (HarperVia, 343 pages, $27.99): "Death and life are in the power of the tongue." The line is typically taken as an exhortation to righteous speech, but in this wily, appealing novel it becomes a testament to the saving grace of language itself, and to the corrosive consequences when it falls out of use and disappears.

title: 'Cult of Glory' Review: Falling Heroes
summary: Author Doug J. Swanson punctures the myth of the Texas Rangers as 'quiet, deliberate gentle' men, describing them instead as 'the 'violent instruments of repression.'. In 1935, Walter Prescott Webb-one of the 20th century's leading historians of Texas and the wider American West-published "The Texas Rangers: A Century of Frontier Defense." Clocking in at more than 550 pages, the book chronicled the exploits of the most famous law-enforcement outfit in the world. Crucial to Webb's study were the interviews he conducted with dozens of active and former Rangers, some of whom had served during the especially tumultuous years between Reconstruction and World War I. Although "The Texas Rangers" remains enormously popular today, it has not aged well. Several decades after it first appeared, the writer Larry McMurtry offered that "the flaw in the book is a flaw of attitude. Webb admired the Rangers inordinately, and as a consequence the book mixes homage with history in a manner one can only think sloppy." Recent historians have been much less generous, faulting Webb's whitewashing of the Rangers' brutal treatment of Indians and Mexicans.

title: Is Tesla's Model Y Crossover the World's Best Car?
summary: After years of extravagant R&D, the Silicon Valley car maker has accumulated a pile of patents and a mountain of innovations. No wonder the Model Y is years ahead of the competition, says Dan Neil.. I WAS DEBATING whether to proclaim the new Tesla Model Y the best car in the world. Given that the all-electric medium-size crossover ($57,190 for the Long Range Dual Motor AWD, as tested) is the most technically advanced electric automobile made; and that electric cars are functionally superior to those powered by internal combustion; there is a certain Vulcan logic to it.

title: Sean Healey Raised Funds for Research Into ALS Treatments
summary: Chief executive of investment firm AMG, struck by disease, quickly went on the offensive. Two years ago, a week before his 57th birthday, Sean Healey was diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, and had a life expectancy of about three to five years.

title: This Bull Market Isn't as Big as You Think
summary: Just a few big winners are responsible for most of the stock market's rapid recovery. The gap between Wall Street and Main Street has never seemed wider-but much of it is an illusion.

title: Readers Flock to Books About Race Relations
summary: 'White Fragility,' 'How to Be an Antiracist' are among many titles related to racial issues leading Amazon's bestseller list. Books about the history of racism, diversity and race relations are soaring to the top of bestsellers' lists, a sign of growing interest in racial issues amid nationwide protests against police brutality.

title: Children's Books: Sailing the Sea of Stories
summary: Folk tales aren't quaint; their truths never age. In a time of division, they enrich and refresh us. They give us courage.. This has been a distressing week of violent scenes and stark rhetoric. For young readers and their families, at such a time it's perhaps better to turn to stories that enlarge the spirit rather than inflame it. An excellent place to find them is in traditional storytelling, where we encounter every kind of person, predicament and human weakness-and every type of nobility. Folktales, fairy tales, legends and myths may be old, but they're neither quaint nor obsolete. They refresh. They enrich. And at a time of division, they offer encouragement, humility and perspective.

title: 'Shadowplay' Review: Prelude to a Vampire
summary: The story of a young Bram Stoker and his accidental friendship with two giants of the British theater.. You know this story. A young office clerk is sent abroad, to a craggy wilderness, to advise a mysterious client. His fiancée wishes he wouldn't go; she has a Bad Feeling. Nevertheless, off he trots. To sunny Transylvania, in fact (turn right at Budapest, follow signs to the Borgo Pass), where an abundance of garlic-wielding peasants and howling wolves seems to suggest that said client (pale chap, a little odd, sleeps in a coffin) might have an unhealthy interest in his guest's jugular vein. Next thing you know it's bats in the bedchamber, graveyards at midnight, crucifixes being brandished, stakes sharpened, more garlic strewn about and oodles of Atmosphere. "Inside the large room, heavy brocade drapes are closed. A fire spits and gusts in the grate. . . . A single black candle is weeping its wax down the pillar of its alabaster candlestick. 'Good evening?' he tries. Shadows, the crackle of the fire." A door creaks and a disembodied voice is heard. But-what a relief-this is not Count Dracula. And we are not, thank heavens, in Transylvania but in a Dublin hotel room in 1878 witnessing the first encounter between Henry Irving, the legendary English stage actor, and Bram Stoker, office clerk and aspiring playwright, two of three irresistible protagonists in Joseph O'Connor's effervescent new novel, "Shadowplay."

title: What CEOs Said About George Floyd's Death
summary: A look at what the leaders at 35 big companies from Facebook to Bank of America said in response to the killing and recent protests. Executives at big U.S. companies have been speaking out publicly about the killing of George Floyd while in custody of Minneapolis police. Most messages call for unity and condemn racism, but not every company has been using the same language to make its point.

title: Hydroxychloroquine Studies Tied to Data Firm Surgisphere Retracted
summary: Three authors involved in Lancet article that drew scrutiny said they couldn't get full data set behind study; an article in the New England Journal of Medicine was also retracted. Two major studies casting doubt on the ability of antimalaria drugs to treat Covid-19 patients based on data from a little-known Chicago company, Surgisphere Corp., were retracted Thursday.

title: Slack's Tough Act to Follow
summary: Zoom set a high bar for other tech companies benefiting from pandemic's work-from-home surge. As Slack Technologies showed Thursday, not all work-from-home stars are created equal.

title: Payment Problems Rise in Fast-Growing Private-Debt Market
summary: Default rates rise sharply for loans popular with heavily indebted private-equity-backed companies. Debt-repayment problems are increasing among borrowers in the rapidly growing market for private credit, where specialist funds make loans directly to smaller companies often without banks involved.

title: Why Yvonne Orji Thinks 'Insecure' Fans Should Cut Molly Some Slack
summary: The HBO comedy actress unpacks her character's messy season-the first in which she has a stand-alone episode. For three seasons, fans of HBO's Insecure have watched Issa Dee, played by show co-creator Issa Rae, and her best friend, Molly Carter (Yvonne Orji), navigate their love lives, careers and the tensions that can arise in a friendship. Those strains came to a head at the end of the third season when Molly, who had recently gotten out of a relationship with a married man, interfered in Issa's love life and was called out by her friend for assuming the worst in everybody.

title: Trump's Focus Shifts Away From Coronavirus
summary: Even before current wave of protests over George Floyd killing, president and advisers had decided to turn to other issues. WASHINGTON-The White House coronavirus task force is meeting less frequently, the government's top infectious disease expert is getting little face time with President Trump, and the administration's virus-testing coordinator is returning to his previous job.

title: Is Your JC Penney Store Closing? Check the List
summary: Retailer plans to close 154 locations after filing for bankruptcy protection. J.C. Penney Co. is closing 154 of its department stores after filing for bankruptcy protection, as the embattled chain tries to shrink to survive a yearslong slump.

title: NetEase and JD.com Move Toward Hong Kong Listings
summary: As tensions between the U.S. and China escalate, Chinese companies are looking to secure secondary listings closer to home. Two of China's most valuable U.S.-listed companies progressed toward listings in Hong Kong, with e-commerce giant JD.com Inc. beginning to take orders for its stock sale and online-gaming group NetEase Inc. pricing its fundraising.

title: Why Stamp Collecting Is Suddenly Back in Vogue
summary: Its analog appeal is sparking the interest of millennials, housebound travelers and anyone who needs the 'Zen' of looking at tiny artwork. Plus: a guide to buying and selling.. GORGING ON HBO in Washington, D.C., while waiting for the city to unlock itself, my eye wandered from TV to the media cabinet shelf where my long-forgotten stamp albums sat. An inveterate traveler now marooned by pestilence, I began leafing through them, every postmark a childhood touchstone: The Belgian king, dyed an unflattering rose, that I had nicknamed "pink head." The Czech hockey team that seemed sad to be trapped behind their Iron Curtain. The tiny Laotian mahout atop his enormous elephant sparked dreams of jungle journeys across Southeast Asia. Each stamp was a ticket to a destination I would, and did, later visit.

title: Each Morning, After Protests, America Cleans Up
summary: Communities are joining together to paint over graffiti and sweep up debris. Protests and looting occurring nightly across America are being followed by a different phenomenon the following mornings: volunteers swooping in to clean up the garbage, debris and graffiti that is often left behind.

title: Protesters Grapple With Coronavirus Infection Risks
summary: Inspired by a global civil-rights moment, many are willing to take the risk. On Monday morning, Olivier Plummer steeled himself for his first protest for George Floyd in New York City, after struggling for days between a sense of duty to a growing movement and fear over a deadly pandemic.

title: As College Teams Return, So Does the Coronavirus
summary: This past week, Iowa State, Oklahoma State, Marshall, Mississippi and Alabama disclosed multiple positive cases among athletes and athletic personnel. College athletes are returning to campus for voluntary workouts following the coronavirus lockdowns. And already, coronavirus cases are coming with them.

title: Are Memories of 2009 Adding Fuel to the Market Fire?
summary: Many investors failed to catch the best of the post-2008 rally. Fears of missing out again may explain the recent 'dash for trash.'. Traumas tend to have long-lasting psychological effects. In financial markets, the 2008 crash scarred a whole generation-but maybe the 2009 rebound did too.

title: China's REITs to Riches Story May Not End Well
summary: Without a stronger base of long term institutional investors-and attractive assets-they could fall short. Real-estate investment trusts, investment vehicles backed by income-generating properties like offices or hotels, will likely come to China soon.

title: Japanese Births Fall Again, Despite Abe's Drive to Encourage Families
summary: One of the world's oldest nations becomes more reliant on immigration to keep its population from a rapid decline. TOKYO-Japan's drive to lift its birthrate is fizzling, leaving one of the world's oldest nations more reliant on immigration to keep its population from a rapid decline.

title: Ten Handbags for Summer Outings (or Innings)
summary: Venturing out or staying in with summery, natural-element-inclusive bags-that still retain a classic shape. WOVEN TOGETHER The beach-ready tote gets a raw edge with rope and embroidery. Celine by Hedi Slimane bag, $1,100, celine.com

title: Walmart Wants to Turn Rags Into Riches
summary: Used clothing may be tried, but it's still true. Even amid a pandemic, the retail giant wants in.. Americans are so hot for used clothing that they'll even buy it during a pandemic. At least that is what Walmart is betting.

title: In Race for Covid-19 Vaccine, China Tries for a Coup
summary: Chinese companies are behind five of the 10 candidates for a coronavirus vaccine. The U.S. is home to the world's biggest and best-known pharmaceutical companies. But China is giving the U.S. a run for its money in the race to develop a vaccine for Covid-19-a feat that would instantly change the dynamics of the fight against the deadly virus, and the geopolitical competition between the U.S. and China.

title: Tie-Dye: Not Just for Summer Camp
summary: Seven ways to try the trend that don't involve a single backyard rubber band. All knits should be this groovy. Alanui sweater, $828, farfetch.com

title: Colorblind Users Push Technology Designers to Use Signals Beyond Color
summary: Simple user interface tweaks make life easier for colorblind people. Leaving a Zoom meeting used to be a challenge for Marta Olea, a university professor based in Madrid. Ms. Olea is colorblind so could not see the app's red-on-black "Leave Meeting" text on her computer screen. A large proportion of the 300 million people living with color vision deficiency world-wide would have trouble finding the button too. The most common forms of the condition affect a person's ability to clearly see shades of green and red.

title: Should You Let a Machine Mix Your Next Drink?
summary: Keurig-style cocktail gadgets can quickly mix you a whiskey sour while you wait for the corner bar to open. Still, you might be wiser crafting your own.. I MISS THE PERFECT daiquiri: the pre-pandemic one made at Neat in Los Angeles, mixed with overproof Smith & Cross rum and topped with a crunchy dehydrated lime slice.

title: France Bet Soccer Couldn't Resume. Then Everyone Else Brought It Back.
summary: Club owners are suing the league over its decision to cancel the end of the 2019-20 season. PARIS-France was still stuck indoors when the country made one of the most painful and expensive decisions in the country's sporting history. With 101 matches left unplayed, the national soccer league pulled the plug on its season in late April. Pro sports were the least essential work.

title: Victoria's Secret's U.K. Arm Files for Creditor Protection
summary: L Brands, the owner of Victoria's Secret, is using a 'light-touch administration' that allows management to keep running the business. LONDON-The British unit of Victoria's Secret owner L Brands Inc. filed for protection from creditors Friday as it grapples with disruption wreaked by the coronavirus pandemic, in a move that could result in the sale of the business.

title: Democrats Push to Block Trump-Requested Cuts to Community Policing Programs
summary: Administration seeks to fold offices into other parts of DOJ; Chamber of Commerce gives Kris Kobach cold shoulder. PROTESTS DRAW ATTENTION TO TRUMP-REQUESTED CUTS to community policing and mediation programs at the Justice Department. The administration's 2021 budget, like all its previous budgets, recommended eliminating the Community Relations Services and Community Oriented Policing Services and placing their functions under other parts of the department to "improve efficiency." Both comprise relatively small parts of the DOJ budget, costing $15.5 million and $275.5 million, respectively, and would retain limited funding if moved. Rep. Robert Aderholt, the top Republican on the House appropriations subcommittee for the Justice Department, has questioned why the community programs would be less effective if they were merged with other divisions.

title: The Bulls Have Taken Back the Stock Market
summary: The S&P 500 is up nearly 40% in just the past 50 trading days, the largest such rally since 1957. The bulls are in the driver's seat again. Stocks rose this week, with investors seizing on incrementally good economic news and ignoring the clashes in the streets, the odds of a long, drawn-out recovery and even the potential resumption of the U.S.-China trade war.

title: U.S. Distribution of Covid-19 Drug Improved but Still Wasn't Enough
summary: Federal government shipped coronavirus therapy in larger volumes and more widely, but it was insufficient to treat all hospitalized patients. After a rocky start, the federal government sent nearly a half-million doses of Covid-19 drug remdesivir to states over three weeks last month, but the supplies weren't enough to treat the tens of thousands of hospitalized patients, a Wall Street Journal analysis of shipment and hospitalization data found.

title: College Inc. Faces a Sticker-Price Reckoning
summary: A business bigger than Big Tech needs to adapt as learning from home exposes poor value for money.. Asked where he went to college in a job interview, Kenan Thompson mumbled, tried to change the subject and finally faked a heart attack.

title: Italians Are Rushing to See the Sights Before Tourists Flock Back to Rome
summary: Resume Subscription. ROME-In the eight years Elena Bucceri has lived across from the Colosseum, she has never set foot inside it-until this week, when she had the place nearly to herself.

title: Floyd Memorial Followed by 10th Night of Protests
summary: Judge sets bail of $750,000 for each of the three ex-police officers charged with aiding and abetting his killing. MINNEAPOLIS-The family of George Floyd stood in front of thousands in and around the chapel at North Central University here for a memorial service Thursday, as calls from the podium to change the American justice system were echoed by protesters across the country.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Oliver Williamson, Nobel Economics Winner, Studied Inner Life of Firms
summary: Berkeley professor explored risks and rewards of companies that outsource or make things in-house. When Oliver Williamson was beginning his career in the 1960s, economic models typically treated companies as simple entities that responded rationally to supply, demand and other signals. Dr. Williamson had a hunch that companies could be examined at a much deeper level to determine how they made choices and what sorts of organizational structures worked best.

title: Las Vegas Reopens; Covid-19 Ravages Latin America
summary: Concern rises that demonstrations in response to killing of George Floyd could lead to surge of infections. • The U.S. coronavirus death toll passed 108,000 while reported cases topped 1.8 million, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. Cases world-wide passed 6.6 million, and deaths stood at more than 389,000. Experts say official totals likely understate the extent of the pandemic, in part because of differing testing and reporting standards.

title: Musk Calls for Amazon Breakup in Spat With Bezos
summary: E-commerce giant's power as publisher questioned. Elon Musk blasted Amazon.com Inc. and its founder Jeff Bezos Thursday, after the online retail giant rejected a book about the coronavirus pandemic, a clash that highlights the power some big tech companies wield over speech.

title: S&P 500 Drops, Halting This Week's Rally
summary: The S&P 500 slips, breaking a four-session winning streak. The S&P 500 broke a four-session winning streak in a volatile trading session that forced investors to weigh their optimism about the reopening of the economy against data that showed the pandemic's continued toll.

title: U.S. Nursing Home Population Shrank 10% This Year
summary: New federal data show facilities' occupancy fell by nearly 100,000 amid coronavirus deaths, loss of new admissions, among other causes. The coronavirus pandemic dealt a crushing blow to nursing homes across the U.S., driving down their occupancy by nearly 100,000 residents between the end of 2019 and late May, according to new federal data.
